reviewText:
When I saw the first comparison to Planescape, I was surprised. When I saw 5 more, I nearly vomited blood. Compounded with all the 5-star reviews, I could only wonder if I played an entirely different game that also happened to be called The Cat Lady.
Like 99% of people who buy this, I was attracted by the visual and thematic grittiness. Unlike 99% of people who then reviewed it, I was unimpressed after seeing that the grit was nothing more than a veneer, obscuring unconvincingly delivered acting and an utterly shallow treatment of the themes of depression and suicide, which act as little more than vehicles for plot progression rather than subjects explored in ANY depth or commented upon meaningfully.
Even the plodding monotone in which the protagonist speaks screams shallowness. Depressed people aren't husks, incapable of voice modulation. The monotone should have been used where it made sense and not as a constant and incredibly tactless means of perpetuating some half-baked atmosphere.
The writing was barely serviceable in some parts and immersion-breakingly full of exposition in others. Susan's evolution as a character is definitely told and not shown, making changes feel forced and unexpected. Showing without telling is one of the top things that distinguishes good writing from bad.
The puzzles were, for the most part, so straight forward, they may as well have prompted you to click around on the screen while we artificially and meaninglessly extend your play time".
The art style was reminiscent of that found in Scary Stories to Tell in the Dark. The individual pieces were
hoursPlayed: but often assembled somewhat thoughtlessly.\nClearly the majority is content to just be fed "dark subject matter" even if it's at the most superficial level. If you're looking for some depth
voteText: there isn't any to plumb here."

reviewText:
I hate it when I follow seemingly spectacular reviews from many people, but then end up with a lackluster mess of an experience when I actually end up playing the game. TLDR at the end.

PROS:

Gritty and atmospheric at times (Con - one note in others)

Some of the characters are voiced really well, and lend some much needed life to the drab and mostly colorless world.

Some of the writing in the game is excellent, and evokes a sense of understanding and connectivity to humanity itself.

CONS:

The other characters that are voiced range from uninteresting to downright jarring and hideous (especially when it's in the case of one of the main characters in the story arch).

The rest of the writing ranges from uninspired filler to something you might receive at the end of a fourth grade literacy examination.

Terrible save system. Often you have no option to save (during cutscenes and conversations, which run through the majority of the game). At one point (luckily early in the game) I quit because I thought it would autosave, based on seeing no hint of a save menu. Only I found upon rebooting the game, that I had to restart from the beginning. For reference, in case you choose to get this game despite my warnings, it's the esc key. You can only use it during sections where you can move your character around.

No skipping cutscenes/conversations. You must (space key) skip through the dialogue one piece at a time. For other things, such as scripted character movements, you must simply wait. Issues like these simply should not exist within games these days. There's no excuse.

TLDR:

The more I played, the more I realized I was wasting my time with something that would inevitably just continue to dissapoint me even further. If you're into self-pity and adolescent tantrum states, as well as a system which does not allow for adaptability to real-life eventualities (such as having to stop playing without advance notice) play this game. As someone who values his time, and wishes to save the time of other gamers, I cannot recommend this title.

reviewText:
The Cat Lady is a psychological horror game developed by Harvester Games, placing you in the role of a 40 year old woman named Susan Ashworth. Susan is suicidal, and succeeded in killing herself by taking too many pills. She soon discovers that she has a special gift, which must be used to confront five specific people who will change her life. I won’t go into too much more detail, as it will spoil the game, but it’s a very compelling story. The way it is presented to you through the extensive dialogue in-game just draws you deeper and deeper into it. Buckle up for a dark and gory experience.

Gameplay is extremely simple: you can only move Susan left or right, and interact with various objects and people in her environment. Often times, you can pick up and use items throughout each chapter at certain points. Many of these items are required to progress within the narrative and the story. There are many characters to meet and interact with, and depending on your choices, different outcomes and dialogue options.


Every single line of dialogue is fully voiced, and very well done. You can actually feel the emotions of each character through their voices, adding to the immersion factor and connecting the player to Susan on an empathetic level.

The music is very engaging as well, always setting the right mood and tone for each scene. The game is filled with chilling atmospheric tracks done by featured artists such as micAmic, Warmer, 5iah, and Tears of Mars. The soundtrack really fits the game well in every single scene. The developers did a wonderful job with this title, and you will find yourself even more drawn in thanks to the fantastic music and atmospheric sound effects.

The game is of decent length, requiring only about 7-10 hours of play to complete, but oh…what an experience that 7-10 hours is! If you ever get the opportunity to purchase this game, give it a try.

Recommended
Be sure to check out Nerd House Gaming for more reviews!

reviewText:
Pacing is very slow in between the bits of actual puzzle solving. Story is eh. Kinda all over the place and it feels like a bunch of traumatic experiences were thrown together to try and force some sort of empathy for the main character. The slow pacing makes some puzzles tedious. Also the fog area lagged my computer so terribly. There seems to be no fix for it except turning up the settings just to pass that one section.

The mechanic for using items is a bit cumbersome. I wouldn't recommend this game if you do not have patience.
If you like creepy gorey serial killer drama then it's worth a play. Otherwise for the average gamer I don't see this one being much of a hit.

Also having a mental break down from microwaving a hamburger too long was pretty funny.

EDIT: Finally finished the game and got the good ending. I think cutting down some of the repetitive dialog, speeding up the game play with a smoother item system, possibly making the walk cycle faster would really streamline the game to a point I'd recommend this to my friends.

reviewText:
This game is actually really decent. It dials back the graphics for an old school feel, but has a twisted and sometimes scary quality that catches you by surprise. The first half of it is actually fantastic.

Then the story continues into a dull, badly written, d-list movie script that'll leave a bad taste in your mouth.

Don't get me wrong, I enjoyed the story. It just seems like it started as a lit fuse to a bomb climax, but instead was a complete dud. For the price, it's worth checking out if you have some time to kill. Just don't set your hopes too high, you'll get reeled in and have the rug pulled from under you.

Wow, was I ever misled by reviews on this one. The Cat Lady is so bland, slow, and uneventful that 90% of it feels like a walking simulator, the plot is so utterly random and often silly, and frankly it's ugly as hell. There's really nothing to solve, either, you just wander around and eventually bad things happen to you. Over and over.

The story is actually kind of funny if you're really, really high, but then the rest of the game is even more insufferable. Just because it's indie and it's about angst doesn't mean it's any good.

Everyone says that if you've been suicidal and depressed it'll hit home, but I've been there and it was still a total farce to me. If the main character didn't just shuffle everywhere, and if the writing didn't sound like it came out of a choose your own adventure book, maybe I could enjoy it. As it is, I don't know what everyone is smoking, but this game is terrible.
voteText: 5 of 18 people (28%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This is interactive fiction for clinically depressed teenagers and the occasional nu-metal soundtrack hints to the real demographics of this game.

There's not much of an adventure game, the mechanics and UI are quite basic and so are the few puzzles. The storyline that should in theory hold this up is, while captivating for a couple of chapters, gets quite cliché and silly towards the end. It's a story that would very much like you to think it has a deeper meaning, but comes out as quite banal reflections on regret and redemtion.

I would have loved it if it went further in it's narrative concept, but as it is we are left with a brooding protagonist without much at all to say.

From the glowing reviews here, I had expected more.

reviewText: I really tried to like this game, I was expecting a really good indie horror/psyche study experience. I know it's more of an interactive novel than a game, so I won't really mention any of the gameplay other than the fact that it sometimes is clunky and that can detract heavily from the game. It's not very well optimized. Other than that, the game does what it is supposed to do very well, which is give you a solid mindset from the point of veiw of a depressed 40-something woman. The main character and her writing are very well done, and the rest of the story reflects that. The only problem with the spectacular writing for story and the main character is that it really points out the flaws and lackluster writing/voice acting in every other character. It really seems like all the characters are secondary thoughts, plot devices to only move the story further. Other than that, it's just a slow moving bummer. The story, like I said, does what it sets out to do very well, which is to show a clear and accurate look at depression. The story moves slow enough that it feels like time is meaningless because you will always have to deal with the troubles in the game. I opted to kill myself (by stopping playing the game) early, so I honestly can't say whether I know if the ending is better than the story and pacing. I can appreciate art, but theater of pain can only hold me for so long, and this game tried to hold me for longer than it was worth.

reviewText:
A visually oriented psychological horror adventure game with rather shallow and unrealistic characters, poor dialogue, contrived and easy puzzles, crippled interface and finally; good art, atmosphere and at times sound. As an adventure game this game doesn't cut it. As psychological horror it falls flat on its face due to reasons laid out in more detail below.

I can't recommend this game mainly because it fails at what it seems to strive for: psychological horror and meaningful dialogue. The dialogues are extensive, and they consist mostly of filler back-and-forth bickering and unimaginative small-talk, sometimes attempting to be humorous despite the bleak circumstances and surroundings but practically just managing to break the immersion. There are lengthy pauses in the dialogue that you can't skip, and while I understand they were put there to put emphasis on lines and allow for a few seconds of contemplation, after you realize the dialogue is thoroughly shallow and void of depth they just become an annoying, arbitrary speed bump for advancing in the game. It is of course even more annoying if you go back just to get achievements.

Cursing is used with good taste for the most part, i.e. there's not too much of it, and the voice actors mostly manage not to sound ridiculous dropping the F-bombs here and there.

The interface is terrible. You play the game using WASD (up left down right) and enter. Space (and enter) skips a line of dialogue. Movement is in one dimension; you can either walk left or right. When you come across a hotspot, its name is displayed and you can interact with it by pressing up. This opens a list of possible actions such as examine"

reviewText:
Like you see with a lot of games these days The Cat Lady is about telling a story instead of about playing a game. The gameplay is just slapped on to it to make it a game instead of an animation. The reason for this is probably that there is more money to make as game than as animation or as ebook and cheaper to produce than as movie. While all these other mediums would be much better suited for it. Because you can just watch the story unfold instead of having to go through the tedious gameplay.

The controls make the gameplay even more annoying and would be much better as point and click instead of using the arrow keys. It's maybe designed this way too feel the a bit like Susan, but it just pisses you off. The artstyle isn't the best looking, but really fits the mood the game tries to set. The resolution of the game is really low and you can't change it too your native resolution which is always annoying.

It's just too bad it isn't on a other medium, because the world and the story look interesting. But if you really want to see the story you better of watching a let's play than actually playing the game.

reviewText:
My acquaintance with this game began when Steam recommended it for me after I bought Fran Bow. The game's summary was very intriguing. It said the game is about a woman who decided to end her life and about her afterlife experience, or something like that, doesn't really matter. I personally enjoy games like that. Drawn-like 2d environment was very nice too, positive reviews were very promising, so I decided to buy this game too.

When I played a game for a while, I felt, that I was fooled, so to speak. The first reason for that feeling is this. When you see an intro scene which lasts for 5 minutes, it's OK, but when you see such a scene or even a scene twice as long as an intro after every minute you were in controll of your character, this is really annoying. Also there might be a dialog followed by a cutscene, again followed by a dialog (like half an hour overall). This is really boring.

Susan Ashworth, a character controlled by player, is extremely slow. It might seem that she is not only mentally ill, but also ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. I do not mean that scene when she took her medication. No, it's her ordinary behaviour to act and move slowly. So gameplay is reduced to this: move from one side of a room to another with speed of a turtle, have a long and boring conversation, watch a long cutscene, repeat again.

Actually, there are some tough puzzles in the game, but they are not logical, you just need what they call non-standard thinking" to solve them. There are also plenty of gameplay elements and puzzles which do not affect the game at all. Like the one with two rooms guarded by dolls or red and blue bars. Sometimes there is a red bar in a corner of the screen

reviewText:
A perplexing adventure game... is all I can really say about this.

It starts off promising; terrible graphics aside, the protagonist is a 40-year old woman, a demographic rarely seen in games, and one I appreciate being there. She tries to kill herself and this sends her into a fantasy world, at which point the game starts.

Cat lady is a supremely boring game. You may say that I think that due to the type of content alone, but no, the game is just dull. It's completely one dimensional, you can only move left and right. King's quest for DOS allowed for more exploration than this game. Movement is slow as balls, which is very noticable when you're plodding from left to right with nothing much to do. The puzzles are almost non-existant; the game merely tells you to tick off every option on the few interactive objects you come across until you progress, and any time the game does force you to think, the games pace makes it unbearable.

I assume the game was made like this so you could appreciate the backgrounds and environment, which are... relatively good, I suppose. A lot of love has gone into them, but they are nothing extraordinary.

Cat Lady gets no reccomendation from me, I'm afraid, there are thousands of other, better adventure games out there. Does it work as an exploratory journey, rather than as a game? I dont really think so, but hey, that's just my opinion.

reviewText:
This game was flaming dreadful. But i was intrigued to keep playing. An awful, awful first impression. Holy cow it was ugly. I stuck at it, through the walking from one end of the screen, and back again, 100 times. I just stuck at it. It got worse, but i stuck at it.

I couldn't get past it's ugliness. It was just terrible. The music fell flat on so many occasions and made me cringe at some points, it felt very amateur and it just didn't fit right at certain scenes. Some of the voice acting was hilariously bad. Susan's voice wasn't badly acted, but sometimes it didn't quite 'fit'. It felt as though she was trying a little too hard on the sounding dreary and depressed tone that it became very monotone as the game went on. Even when faced with grosteque and terrifying situations, she was sarcastic and dreary.

I liked Mitzi, she was belivable and she was sweet. She was a well rounded character in a game that was otherwise devoid of them (think Pest Control dude, seriously...). Her voice actress was really great.


I was moved on a couple of occasions, (without spoiling anything) one involving Liz, and one involving Zoe. The scenes lingered for just the right amount of time for it to sink in, and it was touching. I thought it a huge shame that i felt unable to truly believe in Susan's depression and sadness. I felt that it was just textbook - bad things have happened to this woman, she's ended up miserable and depressed. Why not have it so that she's a woman with good prospects, a nice family life, living in a nice area, and yet she's burderned with depression? A story centered around her struggles with it despite her 'have-it-all' life could have been really interesting. People say 'what have you got to be depressed about?', unknowing that's not how depression works. It seems though that Susan Ashworth has a million and one things to be depressed about, and it's just too easy. Depression is much much deeper than what this game portrays it as. Mitzi asks Susan at one point 'What is depression like?' and Susan answers 'It's feeling as though all i want to do is die...but instead i have to live'. Simple as that apparently. And that is what the entire game is based on, Susan Ashworth being miserable because she is alive.


I wanted so much more from a game that looked so gritty and strangely dark. I wasn't expecting the gore and grotesque nature of it. I didn't feel it was justified, it was a little random if anything. It was a game full of bad guys, with Susan being a misery to play, i didn't connect with her as she took on a bunch of fairytale weirdos. Weirdos that i've seen a thousand times before in games and films. There was nothing unique or new about them, some even coming across as silly, rather than frightening. Mitzi was a small ray of light in a really really bleak setting, she brought a feeling of real life to the game (although i must admit her own story and motives were far fetched and not entirely realistic). The ending let me down - it summarised depression as something you just shutup and get on with. Something it seemed Susan HAD been doing up until she killed herself at the very beginning of the game! It was an ending without feeling, without real care for what happened next. You wrapped things up (kinda, i mean, half of it made no sense) and yet despite all of the disturbing and terrible things Susan had experienced, she spoke as though she'd just had a lousy week.

I was left with the question of 'what the hell did i just play?'.

I wish it would have been a game based on my original assumptions - Playing as a lady who lives with and looks after a bunch of cats. At least that would have had a deeper storyline.

reviewText:
I get what the game is trying to do, but it's not succeeding in any way. I like the premise of the game, 40-something year old, suicidal woman as a protagonist, you don't see that very often. But that's pretty much where all the good things end in this game.

The artstyle is pretentious, choppy and ugly. Some might think it's artistic and retro, but it really isn't, it's just plain old ugly. Dialogue is horrible, both voice acting and writing. Every character sounds the same, and every character is very monotone and single-minded. I get that they were going for grim, dark, depressed style of feeling, but it just comes off as boring.

As for boring, that's what the gameplay is, among other things. All the puzzles are incredibly easy, but at the same time take a lot of work, walking around, looking for arbitrary hints that might be objects you can interact with, or just part of the backround, you can never tell. It's a point and click adventure, without the point, the click or the adventure.

To top it all off, controls are horrible and clunky, the whole game is unresponsive and unstable, the settings don't seem to do anything and if you try to put it on fullscreen, it just freezes on startup. (Even when run in a window, it took several minutes to go from is it frozen?" to "Holy ♥♥♥♥
date: it took that long to launch?!")\n\nAll in all
recommended: I can't recommend the game in any way. It had potential

reviewText:
While not really so much a game as it is a point and click story requiring no skill, the only risk-reward scenario you face is crossing your fingers and hoping you select the line of response dialog that generates the least amount of back-and-forth and actually progresses the story.  Worst yet. you cannot skip any of the monotonous drivel as it is spewed out at a snail's pace like an elderly feline choking on it's own hairball.

You walk all the way right and find a key, you walk all the way left and find a key.  Then there's literally 30 minutes of dialog between you and the crazy cat lady who sounds like a mix of Frau Farbissina and Angelica Houston in 'The Witches'.  Holy ♥♥♥♥.  If I wanted to be told a story I'd go back to kindergarten.

The publisher must've been smoking some really good catnip to think this was worthy of being brought to the masses.

In short, The Crazy Cat Lady feels as if it were freshly dug out of the litter box.  Thank gods I'm a dog person.

Music was pretty good though.

reviewText:
The Cat Lady is a solid horror point-and-click adventure, but I can't say it's something I'll recommend.

The story focuses on Susan Ashworth, a suicide victim struggling with depression. The game tries to wrap an odd mix of metaphorical demons with real life psychotic criminals and murders. The aspect of the real life nemeses who were out to get Susan were far from realistic or down to Earth. Other than her neighbor, these colorful villians seems like they could have been torn out of a comic book. This strong contrast with what is believable and what is fat'fetched didn't sit well with me.

The puzzles in the game started to feel less refined as the game went on, and more like they were just placed in there to give the player something to do. Additionally, certain odd choices of background ambience and sound effect also brought me out of the experience;
Such as shouting out loud while trying to sneak around, or having background ambience of doors opening and closing when you know there's no one else moving in the entire house. I could go on with a laundry list of events in game, but the larger problem is how the game portrays itself as whole.

While these mismatched events would seem to be purposefully comical, it doesn't seem to be done with such intent.
Such as that one long drawn out scene being that phone call with an incompetent emegency call handler. Which would have be hilarious if it was framed ever so differently.
Even the multitude of misfortune that Susan Ashworth runs into seems oddly comical, but yet the game doesn't seem to acknowledge it.

I do have one point where the game stood out for me, it's Chapter 2. It had one scene to establish some missing background of your version of Susan Ashworth while in a session with the psychiatrist Doctor Xaiver. The player has to pick rather personal information Susan would share, from her relationship with her parents and her daily routines. There weren't any options to omit a reply, so it felt much more intimate for to me as the player answering for Susan. It was blurring the lines where I was trying to keep Susan faithful with what has already been established with her character while projecting myself onto her as well.

Ultimately, I felt it could have been better polished. It's an okay game but not a memoriable one.
voteText: 8 of 34 people (24%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
From what I've played this game doesn't really appeal to me, it has been so far very linear to a point where I'm not sure why they give you the option to choose what you say to people, because I always find myself having to speak all of the options eventually. The whole thing so far seems to be trying too hard to be dark, scary and artistic but it comes across more as bland, slow and boring.

The gameplay is not up to the standard of even the oldest point and click adventures as you can't use the mouse, you simply press the left and right buttons on the keyboard to walk around and press up to interact with things, which makes the puzzles and general gameplay feel tedious.

Perhaps my distaste for the game stems from the fact I am not sympathetic towards the protagonist, in the time I've played it is not explained why she is depressed and wants to commit suicide, for all I know one of her cats died. I'm all in favour for artistic and surreal story telling but in this game a lot of it feels cliche, as though I was inside a highschool kid's art project.

The music however has been alright, I don't want to say good because I haven't really heard enough of it, but it is definitely carrying the game for me at this point. I will continue to play the game for at least another hour when I can be bothered to sit through it and if there are any improvements I will update this review, but I am not confident that the game will have any significant improvement. This game cost me $3.39 and even that feels like a lot for this game, very glad I did not have to pay the original $10.00

reviewText: Whenever I consider buying a new horror game or atmospheric" minimalist game
date: I think "will it be as bad as The Cat Lady?"\n\nThe Cat Lady tries to sell itself as having bad graphics that hide a great story and/or gameplay
recommended: but that's just not true.\n\nThe story is tired and overdone. Anyone that's watched horror movies or played any number of videogames won't find the "life after death" tropes interesting or new
hoursPlayed:
and the dialogue and character development sounds like it was written by someone with the emotional depth of a high schooler. A main part of the plot is literally "you didn't do enough to enjoy life and then you killed yourself so now you're being punished." It's like a really longwinded "YOLO."

The gameplay is basically what you would expect from a free online flash game. There are a lot of online flash games that are more recommendable than this one.

In the end
